Scheduling

Class DirectionDistance

  • java.lang.Object
    • Scheduling.DirectionDistance

  • public class DirectionDistance
extends java.lang.Object
    The purpose of this class is to find the distance and direction of two entities based on the values for the two entities longitude and latitude which are then converted to miles to be able to tell the distance and then are analyzed with trig functions to find the direct needed to travel from the fist entity to the second
    Since:
    3/1/2021

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DirectionDistance(double longitude_1, double latitude_1, double longitude_2, double latitude_2)
      This is the constructor for the distance and direction calculations, which takes the coordinates for the two locations, with the starting location entered first and the end location entered second

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.String get_direction()
      Used to return the direction the object would need to head in to get to the second location The calculations used are based on the inverse tan value of the distance x and y found by the difference between the values which finds the angle value from 0-90 which is then added to the correct value for the start of the angle calculation based on the relative quadrant the second entity is in if the first entity is viewed as the relative origin of the two points.
      double get_distance()
      Used to return the distance between the two points in miles by converting the units of the longitude and latitude and the euclidean distance found
      double round(double value, int places)
      Used to round the results of the distance calculation to return a better looking result for the graph

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • DirectionDistance

        public DirectionDistance(double longitude_1,
                         double latitude_1,
                         double longitude_2,
                         double latitude_2)
        This is the constructor for the distance and direction calculations, which takes the coordinates for the two locations, with the starting location entered first and the end location entered second
        Parameters:
        longitude_1 - the longitude value for the first entity
        latitude_1 - the latitude value for the first entity
        longitude_2 - the longitude value for the second entity
        latitude_2 - the latitude value for the second entity

    • Method Detail

      • get_distance

        public double get_distance()
        Used to return the distance between the two points in miles by converting the units of the longitude and latitude and the euclidean distance found
        Returns:
        the euclidean distance between the two points (in miles)

      • round

        public double round(double value,
                    int places)
        Used to round the results of the distance calculation to return a better looking result for the graph
        Parameters:
        value - value to truncate
        places - the places to truncate till
        Returns:
        the result of the rounding calculation

      • get_direction

        public java.lang.String get_direction()
        Used to return the direction the object would need to head in to get to the second location The calculations used are based on the inverse tan value of the distance x and y found by the difference between the values which finds the angle value from 0-90 which is then added to the correct value for the start of the angle calculation based on the relative quadrant the second entity is in if the first entity is viewed as the relative origin of the two points. This then leads to the calculation of the distance value to return which is based on the main directions for a map (n, ne, e, se, s, sw, w, nw) and the returned angle values which are viewed to be in hedges around the direction to find the "most" correct answer
        Returns:
        string value for the direction from the first point to the second point
